what: How do I plot these things?
title: Mapping with MACEReports
text: functions create sticks interpolated plots return data forms can plotted however ’d like (base R plotting, ggplot, etc). Basemaps, however, ggplot-specific. Examples vignette use ggplot plotting.

title: Mapping with MACEReports
text: make stickplot, ’ll need: x,y, abundance value (z). function build_sf_sticks return sticks sf (simple features) dataframe. sf dataframes can plotted easily using ggplot2, base r plot. default, ’ll get bar rotated 5 degrees vertical, scaled work plots. can specified differently using arguments rotation bar_scale (see ?build_sf_sticks details) Plotting sticks easy ggplot2::geom_sf():  related function produce legend go sticks, build_stick_legend: default, produces white legend placed bottom right corner plot, proper units standard plots biomss/nmi-2; defaults can modified needed (see ?build_stick_legend). legend can added plot (see ).
code: sticks <- build_sf_sticks(x = shelikof_xyz$START_LONGITUDE, y = shelikof_xyz$START_LATITUDE, z = shelikof_xyz$BIOMASS_NM2) ggplot(sticks) +   geom_sf() stick_legend <- build_stick_legend(stick_data = sticks)

title: Mapping with MACEReports
text: course, far isn’t great way look data! need basemap. function get_basemap_layers returns background map uses either high-resolution bathymetric layer ’s appropriate surveys, simple contours user-specifed depths (.e. 100 m, 200 m). can also return variety commonly used layers including NMFS management areas, 3 NMI buffer regions,Steller Sea Lion exclusions. basemaps intended Bering Sea Gulf Alaska. just want basic map, can simply feed sticks dataframe just created function get_basemap_layers. produce land bathymetric layers encompass data. returns ggplot object. find wanting access layers without using ggplot plotting- complain, ’ll add functionality.
code: basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = sticks) # plot it all: the basemap, the sticks, and the legend: basemap +   geom_sf(data = sticks, color = "red") +   stick_legend

title: Mapping with MACEReports
text: often present stickplots multiple groups (say, small fish big fish) separate sticks. can done `build_sf_sticks’:
code: # summarize the data by fish >=30 cm, <30 cm shelikof_by_size <- shelikof_biomass %>%   filter(year == 2021) %>%   mutate(size_class = ifelse(LENGTH >= 30, "big", "small")) %>%   group_by(INTERVAL, size_class, START_LATITUDE, START_LONGITUDE) %>%   summarize(     BIOMASS = sum(BIOMASS),     BIOMASS_NM2 = sum(BIOMASS_NM2)   ) %>%   # cleanup: because we included intervals with zero pollock, the size class will be NA in those cases.   # remove those from this plot!   filter(!is.na(size_class))  # use the 'group_variable' argument in build_sf_sticks to build sticks for each group: sticks_by_size <- build_sf_sticks(x = shelikof_by_size$START_LONGITUDE, y = shelikof_by_size$START_LATITUDE, z = shelikof_by_size$BIOMASS_NM2, group_variable = shelikof_by_size$size_class)  # plot everything again: basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = sticks_by_size) stick_legend <- build_stick_legend(stick_data = sticks_by_size)  basemap +   geom_sf(data = sticks_by_size, aes(color = size_class)) +   stick_legend

title: Mapping with MACEReports
text: bathymetry layer nice plots, inappropriate others. Want keep simple? Specify contours ’d like draw. options : 50, 100, 200, 400, 500, 600, 800, 1000 (values M).  might also want include commonly used layer, NMFS management area 3nmi buffer around land areas. Great. See ?get_basemap_layers current options, ’s ’d add ones:  Since basemap just ggplot object, can add anything might want , change themes, etc.
code: basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = sticks_by_size, bathy = FALSE, contours = c(100, 200, 1000))  # view the plot basemap basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = sticks_by_size, management_regions = TRUE, alaska_3nmi_buffer = TRUE)  # view the plot basemap basemap +   labs(title = "Shelikof") +   theme(panel.border = element_blank())

title: Mapping with MACEReports
text: often present overview figure identifies areas speak text. MACEReports provides list 900 + Alaska area labels, sourced NOAA Office Coast Survey. Want ? Request ! can view alphabetically: course, probably don’t want 900 labels plot. get_area_labels can used return subset area labels appropriate plot. Like basemaps generated get_basemap_layers, ’ll need existing sf spatial dataframe specify limits plot. get_area_labels return labels within extent. case, ’d still 135 labels plot. practical label places talk text. , go get lined add list. can use list combination get_area_labels return labels care . can plot labels using ggplot2::geom_sf_label, ggplot2::geom_sf_text, choice sf plotting methods.
code: all_labels <- available_labels()  # look at the first few knitr::kable(head(all_labels)) # generate an sf object for limits- here, we'll use the sticks object for convenience sticks <- build_sf_sticks(x = shelikof_xyz$START_LONGITUDE, y = shelikof_xyz$START_LATITUDE, z = shelikof_xyz$BIOMASS_NM2)  # use this to return all the labels in this extent all_labels_in_extent <- get_area_labels(plot_limits_data = sticks) # get a list of labels you refer to in the text goa_labels_to_get <- c(   "Shumagin Islands", "Alaska Peninsula", "Shelikof Strait",   "Kodiak Island", "Korovin Island",   "Cape Igvak" )  # use this to return only the labels that are both on the list AND within the plot extent plot_labels <- get_area_labels(plot_limits_data = sticks, area_labels_list = goa_labels_to_get)  # add these to a basemap basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = sticks, bathy = FALSE, contours = c(100, 200, 1000))  basemap +   geom_sf_label(data = plot_labels, aes(label = area_name), alpha = 0.8)

title: Mapping with MACEReports
text: sticks MACE favorite, often nice present interpolated map well. might want ? people think pseudo 3-d plots like stickplots bad (argument seems distort data therefore hard interpret). don’t totally agree , agree, interpolated plots another option display distribution abundance. Interpolated plots nice way compare distribution abundance time (lots information small panel). Creating interpolations requires make choices compared creating stickplots. limitations plots can made. Right now, can make maps following regions: ‘shelikof’, ‘summer_goa’, ‘core_ebs’, ‘sca’ (.e. Shelikof Strait winter survey, Summer GOA survey, Summer EBS survey, summer EBS survey within sea lion conservation area). must define domain interpolation. practical terms, means someone needs build polygon defines domain. want create interpolations elsewhere, can work add polygon . define resolution want interpolate. Smaller numbers = finer resolution (slower run times). value can thought distance meters interpolation points. 1000 seems work well Shelikof, 2500 seems fine larger regions. consider long want wait interpolation. ’ve generally using universal kriging latitude + longitude predictor variables, .e. formula like log10(abundance) ~ Lat + Long. works well can slow! estimated point function every observed point- case like EBS, can ~60,000 estimated points, estimated basis ~10,000 observations. can slow! Therefore, function includes options can produce similar output captures abundance distribution, less time. ’ve got options : Inverse Distance Weighting Ordinary Kriging (without local neighborhood estimation, see ) Universal kriging (without local neighborhood) Simple kriging (without local neighborhood) Using local neighborhood (.e. number nearest observations use estimation) speeds things GREATLY seems capture trends estimating without limitation. Testing suggests best compromise speed helpful presentation abundance distribution use universal kriging local neighborhood 200 observations: Note function simply returns dataframe columns ‘x’, ‘y’, ‘z’. x y correspond positions interpolated values; z corresponds estimated value. default, x y coordinates Albers Equal Area projection (can changed out_crs argument get_interpolated_plot_vals), z estimated abundance value (default log10-transformed units, highlight abundance distribution well data; linear values also option using demonstrated water temperature data ). x y points form grid; therefore, represents box equal size can plotted raster.  course, basemap useful color scheme really help . Making basemap requires one additional step, comparison examples stickplots: current limitations functions written, must provide sf object get_basemap_layers function: ’ve got basemap, can add raster (, slightly upgraded color scheme):  additional function get_interpolated_color_bins bin colors make trends easier see. minimum, specify z value:  default, returns log10-sized bins; can modified using style argument get_interpolated_color_bins. See ?get_interpolated_color_bins options, kmeans tends work well. want interpolate compare multiple years, things get bit complex. approach outlined - uses local neighborhood speed plotting- isn’t great comparing across years. constrain extrapolations areas nearby samples using local neighborhood. sample grid changes years, area extrapolation also change. can avoided using local neighborhood. slows things , makes datasets easily comparable. Water temperatures interpolations want interpolate water temperature values instead fish abundance values, modifications make logical interpolation. Namely, ’ll probably want interpolate values linear domain (opposed default interpolations work log10-transformed values). Linear interpolations possible using simple kriging inverse-distance weighting MACEReports. example, sea surface temperatures collected Shelikof winter survey used create interpolated map using simple kriging:
code: interp_vals_2021 <- get_interpolated_plot_vals(x = shelikof_xyz$START_LONGITUDE, y = shelikof_xyz$START_LATITUDE, z = shelikof_xyz$BIOMASS, resolution = 1000, region = "shelikof", interp_type = "universal", neighborhood = 200) #> [1] "Interpolating using universal kridging; this can be very slow! Consider a higher resolution value if this is taking forever (recommended resolution for summer surveys >= 2500; for winter >= 1000)."  # return a small table knitr::kable(head(interp_vals_2021), row.names = FALSE) ggplot() +   geom_raster(data = interp_vals_2021, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = z)) # create an sf object we can use to define the basemap extent extent <- st_as_sf(interp_vals_2021, coords = c("x", "y"), crs = "EPSG:3338")  # use this to return the basemap; return a simple basemap with contours as the bathymetery seems too busy with interpolated maps basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = extent, bathy = FALSE, contours = c(100, 200, 1000)) basemap +   geom_raster(data = interp_vals_2021, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = z)) +   scale_fill_viridis_c(option = "magma") interp_vals_2021$plot_col <- get_interpolated_color_bins(z = interp_vals_2021$z)  basemap +   geom_raster(data = interp_vals_2021, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = plot_col)) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "magma") # summarize example data: biomass per interval, per year shelikof_by_year <- shelikof_biomass %>%   group_by(year, INTERVAL, START_LATITUDE, START_LONGITUDE) %>%   summarize(BIOMASS = sum(BIOMASS))  # loop through each year to return each year's values: interp_by_year <- c() for (i in unique(shelikof_by_year$year)) {   # limit your dataset to one year   tmp_data <- shelikof_by_year[shelikof_by_year$year == i, ]    # get the interpolations for this year: note that no neighborhood is applied   interp_vals <- get_interpolated_plot_vals(x = tmp_data$START_LONGITUDE, y = tmp_data$START_LATITUDE, z = tmp_data$BIOMASS, resolution = 1000, region = "shelikof", interp_type = "universal")    # add a year index   interp_vals$year <- i    # and compile   interp_by_year <- rbind(interp_by_year, interp_vals) } #> [1] "Interpolating using universal kridging; this can be very slow! Consider a higher resolution value if this is taking forever (recommended resolution for summer surveys >= 2500; for winter >= 1000)." #> [1] "Interpolating using universal kridging; this can be very slow! Consider a higher resolution value if this is taking forever (recommended resolution for summer surveys >= 2500; for winter >= 1000)."  # create an sf object we can use to define the basemap extent extent <- st_as_sf(interp_by_year, coords = c("x", "y"), crs = "EPSG:3338")  # use this to return the basemap; return a simple basemap with contours as the bathymetery seems too busy with interpolated maps basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = extent, bathy = FALSE, contours = c(100, 200, 1000))  # bin colors to highlight patterns interp_by_year$plot_col <- get_interpolated_color_bins(z = interp_by_year$z)  # use ggplot to plot, facet plots by year basemap +   geom_raster(data = interp_by_year, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = plot_col)) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "magma") +   facet_wrap(~year, ncol = 2) +   labs(fill = "Biomass (kg)") +   theme(legend.position = "bottom") # get interpolated sea surface temperatures using simple kriging of linear values: interp_temps <- get_interpolated_plot_vals(x = shelikof_sst$LONGITUDE, y = shelikof_sst$LATITUDE, z = shelikof_sst$MEASUREMENT_VALUE, resolution = 1000, region = "shelikof", interp_type = "simple", interp_scale = "linear", neighborhood = 200) #> [1] "Interpolating using simple kriging; this can be very slow! Consider a higher resolution value if this is taking forever (recommended resolution for summer surveys >= 2500; for winter >= 1000" #> [using simple kriging]  # create an sf object we can use to define the basemap extent extent <- st_as_sf(interp_temps, coords = c("x", "y"), crs = "EPSG:3338")  # use this to return the basemap; return a simple basemap with contours as the bathymetery seems too busy with interpolated maps basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = extent, bathy = FALSE, contours = c(100, 200, 1000))  # use ggplot to plot basemap +   geom_raster(data = interp_temps, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = z)) +   scale_fill_distiller(palette = "RdYlBu", direction = -1) +   labs(fill = "Temperature (C)")

title: Mapping with MACEReports
text: Many shapefiles commonly use stored within MACEReports. can handy don’t want use ggplot-flavored basemaps generated get_basemap_layers, example. can also nice flexibility creating figures. meant convenient calling mapping directories place. ’ve got shapefile included, let us know ’ll include . functions see currently available, load script:
code: # check out what is available: available_shapefiles() #> [1] "alaska_3nmi_buffer" #> [1] "alaska_area_labels.gpkg" #> [1] "alaska_bathy_contours" #> [1] "alaska_bathy_raster" #> [1] "alaska_land" #> [1] "alaska_NMFS_management_regions" #> [1] "alaska_race_bathy" #> [1] "canada_land" #> [1] "core_ebs_extrp_polygon" #> [1] "goa_summer_extrap_polygon" #> [1] "russia_land" #> [1] "sca_extrp_polygon" #> [1] "shelikof_extrap_polygon" #> [1] "SSL_critical_habitat" # get a file  ak_management_areas <- get_shapefile(shapefile_name = "alaska_NMFS_management_regions")  # note that this will, by default, return a file projected Albers Equal Area Alaska (EPSG:3338). If you'd prefer something else, select a valid CRS for the crs argument: ak_management_areas <- get_shapefile(shapefile_name = "alaska_NMFS_management_regions", crs = "EPSG:4326")

title: Mapping with MACEReports
text: Maybe ’d like even control bathymetry display- say, different line types colors depth. ’ve got two functions make pretty straightforward: get_shapefile easy_plot_limits. easy_plot_limits just little convenience function maps ggplot don’t deal setting limits based coordinates.
code: # first, go get the 50,100, and 200 m bathymetric lines bathy_lines <- get_shapefile(shapefile_name = 'alaska_bathy_contours') %>%   filter(METERS %in% c(50,100,200))  # get a basemap based on the shelikof stickplots, but leave out the bathymetry basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = sticks, bathy = FALSE)  # now go add your sticks, and the custom bathymetry basemap +   # add the bathy lines with different linetypes for each depth   geom_sf(data = bathy_lines, aes(linetype = factor(METERS))) +   labs(linetype = 'Depth (m)') +   # add some data    geom_sf(data = sticks, color = 'red') +   # use the easy_plot_limits function to handle the limits!    # just feed it the same sf object that you used for your basemap.   # this is required when you bring in a new shapefile that has a greater extent than the basemap   # (in this case, bathy_lines)   easy_plot_limits(plot_limits_data = sticks)

what: Build stick objects from xyz (lat/long/abundance) data for use in stickplots — build_sf_sticks
title: Build stick objects from xyz (lat/long/abundance) data for use in stickplots — build_sf_sticks
text: Accepts xyz data (example, longitude/latitude/abundance) returns vertical 'stick' position. Sticks returned sf LINESTRING objects. objects can plotted using ggplot2::geom_sf() base plot.

title: Build stick objects from xyz (lat/long/abundance) data for use in stickplots — build_sf_sticks
code: build_sf_sticks(   x,   y,   z,   group_variable = NULL,   return_df = NULL,   rotation = 5,   bar_scale = 0.5,   crs = "EPSG:3338" )

title: Build stick objects from xyz (lat/long/abundance) data for use in stickplots — build_sf_sticks
text: x x- position y Y- position z Abundance value (value used scale sticks) group_variable specified, specify group stick; can used identify sticks group. return_df specified, include columns original dataframe returned object. one 'group_variable' 'return_df' specified. rotation Rotation sticks degrees vertical. Default 5 degrees. 0 = rotation; positive values rotate bars clockwise direction. bar_scale relative size sticks. Default ~1/2 total plot height. crs coordinate reference system (CRS) sticks projected. default, objects returned using default CRS (Albers Equal Area Alaska, EPSG 3338). valid projection can specified. Note relies sf::st_crs function- make sure using valid CRS argument.

title: Build stick objects from xyz (lat/long/abundance) data for use in stickplots — build_sf_sticks
code: dat <- data.frame(   "x" = c(-152.2, -150.3, -159.4),   "y" = c(55.2, 55.8, 55.6),   "z" = c(7500, 40000, 28000),   "species" = c("a", "a", "b") )  # sticks can be plotted with ggplot2::geom_sf(), # and Coordinate Reference System (CRS) conversions are handled by sf::st_crs() library(ggplot2) library(sf) #> Linking to GEOS 3.9.3, GDAL 3.5.2, PROJ 8.2.1; sf_use_s2() is TRUE  # you have to provide x,y,z at minimum sticks <- build_sf_sticks(x = dat$x, y = dat$y, z = dat$z)  # plot with ggplot2 geom_sf() ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = sticks)   # or with base r plotting plot(sticks)   # the rotation (from 0) can be specified (in degrees from 0-360). If not specified, # sticks will be rotated to 5 degrees sticks <- build_sf_sticks(x = dat$x, y = dat$y, z = dat$z, rotation = 15)  ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = sticks)   # If a CRS is not specified, none will be assigned; if one is specified, # it will be set using sf st_crs() sticks <- build_sf_sticks(   x = dat$x, y = dat$y, z = dat$z, rotation = 15, crs = 3338,   group_variable = dat$species )  ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = sticks, aes(color = species))   # sticks are automatically scaled so that the largest abundance value # this can be modified with bar_scale argument sticks <- build_sf_sticks(x = dat$x, y = dat$y, z = dat$z, rotation = -5, bar_scale = 2) sticks2 <- build_sf_sticks(x = dat$x, y = dat$y, z = dat$z, rotation = 5, bar_scale = .5)  ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = sticks) +   geom_sf(data = sticks2, color = "red")

code: if (FALSE) { # get a simple dataset to work from: biomass_nmi2 from a single survey shelikof_xyz <- shelikof_biomass %>%   dplyr::filter(year == 2021) %>%   dplyr::group_by(INTERVAL, START_LATITUDE, START_LONGITUDE) %>%   dplyr::summarize(     BIOMASS = sum(BIOMASS),     BIOMASS_NM2 = sum(BIOMASS_NM2)   )  # build a sticks object sticks <- build_sf_sticks(   x = shelikof_xyz$START_LONGITUDE,   y = shelikof_xyz$START_LATITUDE,   z = shelikof_xyz$BIOMASS_NM2 )  # get a list of all the place names in your document goa_labels_to_get <- c(   "Shumagin Islands", "Alaska Peninsula", "Shelikof Strait",   "Kodiak Island", "Cape Kekurnoi", "Cape Nukshak", "Korovin Island",   "Kalsin Bay", "Cape Igvak" )  # use the limits of the sticks to get your labels in the plot area_labels <- get_area_labels(plot_limits_data = sticks, area_labels_list = goa_labels_to_get) }

title: Create a MACE-themed basemap — get_basemap_layers
text: Returns base map. map returned ggplot2 object complex maps can built top . provides land, bathymetry, , optionally, variety common layers including NMFS management areas, 3 NMI buffer #' regions,Steller Sea Lion exclusions. basemaps intended Bering Sea Gulf Alaska. layer slightly larger extent plot_limits_data; users can use plot_expansion parameter fine-tune extent.

title: Create a MACE-themed basemap — get_basemap_layers
code: get_basemap_layers(   plot_limits_data,   bathy = TRUE,   bathy_max_plot_depth = 1000,   contours = NULL,   management_regions = NULL,   SSL_critical_habitat = NULL,   alaska_3nmi_buffer = NULL,   land_fill_color = "#616161",   land_outline_color = "black",   plot_expansion = 0.05 )

title: Create a MACE-themed basemap — get_basemap_layers
text: plot_limits_data sf spatial dataframe; required used define base map extent projection. bathy default, bathymetric baselayer based GEBCO (https://www.gebco.net/) gridded bathymetric dataset included basemap; FALSE, bathymetric baselayer included bathy_max_plot_depth maximum depth want emphasize bathymetric color scale (default 1000 m); helps focus contrast shallower depths emphasize especially deep areas shelf break. contours Provide contour lines requested depths. Specify depths positive numeric values, .e. c(200,100,50) management_regions TRUE, add NMFS management regions basemap SSL_critical_habitat TRUE, add Steller Sea Lion critical habitat buffers basemap alaska_3nmi_buffer TRUE, add ADFG 3 nmi management buffer basemap land_fill_color like different fill color landmasses, specify required ggplot2. land_outline_color like different outline color landmasses, specify required ggplot2. plot_expansion controls amount buffer around basemap (default 5% (0.05) around extent data; set 0-1).

title: Create a MACE-themed basemap — get_basemap_layers
text: list class ggplot containing information required plotting basemap.

title: Create a MACE-themed basemap — get_basemap_layers
text: Mike Levine

title: Create a MACE-themed basemap — get_basemap_layers
code: if (FALSE) { library(ggplot2) library(sf) library(MACEReports)  dat <- data.frame(   "x" = c(-152.2, -150.3, -159.4),   "y" = c(55.2, 55.8, 55.6),   "z" = c(7500, 40000, 28000),   "species" = c("a", "a", "b") )  # create an sf dataframe dat <- sf::st_as_sf(dat, coords = c("x", "y"), crs = 4326)  # convert CRS to a reasonable projection dat <- sf::st_transform(dat, crs = "EPSG:3338")  # return the basemap as a ggplot layer mace_basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = dat)  # note that this basemap will replace the usual call to ggplot() as the start of your plot: mace_basemap +   geom_sf(data = dat, aes(color = species))  # You can add other commonly used MACE layers to the basemap mace_basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = dat, management_regions = TRUE) mace_basemap  mace_basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = dat, alaska_3nmi_buffer = TRUE) mace_basemap  mace_basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = dat, SSL_critical_habitat = TRUE) mace_basemap  mace_basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = dat, bathy = FALSE, contours = c(200, 100, 50)) mace_basemap }

what: Return logical breaks that can be used to plot abundance values — get_interpolated_color_bins
title: Return logical breaks that can be used to plot abundance values — get_interpolated_color_bins

title: Return logical breaks that can be used to plot abundance values — get_interpolated_color_bins
code: get_interpolated_color_bins(z, n_bins = 9, style = "log10", nice_labels = TRUE)

title: Return logical breaks that can be used to plot abundance values — get_interpolated_color_bins
text: z vector abundance values n_bins number bins like return; default 9. ignored style 'log10'. style algorithm used binning; default 'log10', places abundance values log10 bins; 'kmeans' also produces good results. nice_labels return label values linear (vs log) space formatted use plots; meant #' used conjunction values generated get_interpolated_plot_vals, return log10 units.

title: Return logical breaks that can be used to plot abundance values — get_interpolated_color_bins
text: Mike Levine

title: Return logical breaks that can be used to plot abundance values — get_interpolated_color_bins
code: if (FALSE) { # Get some interpolated plot values shelikof_xyz <- shelikof_biomass %>%   filter(year == 2021) %>%   group_by(INTERVAL, START_LATITUDE, START_LONGITUDE) %>%   summarize(     BIOMASS = sum(BIOMASS),     BIOMASS_NM2 = sum(BIOMASS_NM2)   )  interp_vals_2021 <- get_interpolated_plot_vals(x = shelikof_xyz$START_LONGITUDE, y = shelikof_xyz$START_LATITUDE, z = shelikof_xyz$BIOMASS, resolution = 1000, region = "shelikof", interp_type = "universal", neighborhood = 200)  # create an sf object we can use to define the basemap extent extent <- st_as_sf(interp_vals_2021, coords = c("x", "y"), crs = "EPSG:3338")  # # Return a simple basemap with contours as the bathymetery seems too busy with interpolated maps basemap <- get_basemap_layers(plot_limits_data = extent, bathy = FALSE, contours = c(100, 200, 1000))  # Get the interpolated values: at a minimum, provide Z values interp_vals_2021$plot_col <- get_interpolated_color_bins(z = interp_vals_2021$z)  basemap +   geom_raster(data = interp_vals_2021, aes(x = x, y = y, fill = plot_col)) +   scale_fill_viridis_d(option = "magma") }

what: Return predicted biomass values that can be plotted in interpolated abundance and distribution maps — get_interpolated_plot_vals
title: Return predicted biomass values that can be plotted in interpolated abundance and distribution maps — get_interpolated_plot_vals
text: Accepts xyz data (example, longitude/latitude/abundance) returns dataframe interpolated values. number interpolated values returned depends chosen map resolution.objects can plotted using  gpplot2 geom_raster(), base plot, converted rasters.

title: Return predicted biomass values that can be plotted in interpolated abundance and distribution maps — get_interpolated_plot_vals
code: get_interpolated_plot_vals(   x,   y,   z,   resolution,   region,   out_crs = "EPSG:3338",   interp_type,   interp_scale = "log10",   neighborhood = NULL )

title: Return predicted biomass values that can be plotted in interpolated abundance and distribution maps — get_interpolated_plot_vals
text: x Longitude (decimal degrees) y Latitude (decimal degrees) z Quantity (abundance, biomass, temperature, etc) resolution Distance (meters) interpolation points. Recommended values 1000 Shelikof, 2500 summer surveys. region Region make interpolations. Currently, options 'shelikof', 'summer_goa', 'core_ebs', 'sca'. out_crs Coordinate Reference Setting returned interpolation points; default "EPSG:3338" interp_type Interpolation formula apply. Options 'universal', 'ordinary', 'simple', 'idw'. Universal uses universal kridging Latitude Longitude variables; Ordinary uses ordinary kridging, simple uses simple kriging mean set mean(z), idw performs inverse-distance weighting interpolation. Universal kridging comprehensive, slow. IDW coarse, fast. interp_scale default, interpolation done log10-transformed quantities (works well abundance biomass). However, can also interpolate linear domain (works well temperature values). Options 'log10' (default) 'linear'. use linear, recommend using interp_type = 'idw' interp_type = 'simple'. neighborhood (optional) number nearest observations use universal ordinary kridging calculations. default use observations; limiting calculations neighborhood can used speed interpolation. argument passes number nearest arguments use  Gstat::kridge; see Gstat::kridge nmax argument details.

title: Return predicted biomass values that can be plotted in interpolated abundance and distribution maps — get_interpolated_plot_vals
text: dataframe 4 columns: x = Longitude (crs specified out_crs; default default "EPSG:3338") y = Latitude (crs specified out_crs; default default "EPSG:3338") z = abundance value. Note values default Log 10-transformed abundance, tend highlight patterns abundance distribution MACE datasets. Set interp_scale = 'linear' like return values linear domain.

title: Return predicted biomass values that can be plotted in interpolated abundance and distribution maps — get_interpolated_plot_vals
text: Mike Levine
